           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-340218" id="menu-item-340218">

            Partners
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>

        <article class="single post" id="post-single" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
         <div id="post-header">
          <ul id="categories">
           <li class="category" itemprop="about">
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/living/food-living/" rel="category tag">
             Food
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
          <h1 itemprop="name">
           Diane Rehm Examines the Dangers of Monsantos Roundup and Dows Enlist Duo Herbicides
          </h1>
          <div class="meta">
           <span class="author" itemprop="author">
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/author/cole-mellino/" rel="author" title="Posts by Cole Mellino">
             Cole Mellino
            </a>
           </span>
           <span class="sep">
            |
           </span>
           <span class="pubdate">
            February 4, 2015 1:50 pm
           </span>
           <span class="sep">
            |
           </span>
           <a class="comments-link" href="http://ecowatch.com/2015/02/04/diane-rehm-dangers-roundup/#comments">
            Comments
           </a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="post-content" itemprop="text">

             <h2>
              Dont miss out. Stay Informed.
              <span style="color:#000;">
               Get Eco
              </span>
              Watch
              <span style="color:#000;">
               s Top News of the Day.
              </span>
             </h2>
             <div class="gf_browser_unknown gform_wrapper" id="gform_wrapper_21">
              <form action="/2015/02/04/diane-rehm-dangers-roundup/" enctype="multipart/form-data" id="gform_21" method="post">
               <div class="gform_body">
                <ul class="gform_fields top_label form_sublabel_below description_below" id="gform_fields_21">

                  </div>
                 </li>
                </ul>
               </div>
               <div class="gform_footer top_label">
                <input class="gform_button button" id="gform_submit_button_21" onclick='if(window["gf_submitting_21"]){return false;}  if( !jQuery("#gform_21")[0].checkValidity || jQuery("#gform_21")[0].checkValidity()){window["gf_submitting_21"]=true;}  ' tabindex="2" type="submit" value="Sign Up"/>
                <br/>
                <input class="gform_hidden" name="is_submit_21" type="hidden" value="1"/>

                <input class="gform_hidden" name="gform_submit" type="hidden" value="21"/>

                 <input class="gform_hidden" name="gform_unique_id" type="hidden" value=""/>
                 <br/>
                 <input class="gform_hidden" name="state_21" type="hidden" value="WyJbXSIsIjM1ZDNkOGJlMjk1ZTZjNWNhYzE4MjYyZDRkYjJlYjZhIl0="/>

             <p>
              <script type="text/javascript">
               jQuery(document).bind('gform_post_render', function(event, formId, currentPage){if(formId == 21) {if(typeof Placeholders != 'undefined'){
                        Placeholders.enable();
                    }} } );jQuery(document).bind('gform_post_conditional_logic', function(event, formId, fields, isInit){} );

               jQuery(document).ready(function(){jQuery(document).trigger('gform_post_render', [21, 1]) } );
              </script>
             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
           <p>
            Yesterday on NPRs
            <a href="http://thedianerehmshow.org/shows/2015-02-03/environmental_outlook_the_race_against_pests_and_weeds" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'http://thedianerehmshow.org/shows/2015-02-03/environmental_outlook_the_race_against_pests_and_weeds', 'The Diane Rehm Show');" target="_blank">
             <em>
              The Diane Rehm Show
             </em>
            </a>
            , Diane Rehm and her guests discussed the race against pests and weeds, and the recent approval by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) onDow AgroSciences
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/2014/10/15/epa-approves-gmo-pesticide/">
             herbicide Enlist Duo
            </a>
            , a new combination of 2,4-D and
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/2014/03/27/brazil-ban-monsanto-herbicide-toxic/">
             glyphosate
            </a>
            meant to fight chemical-resistant 
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/2014/05/02/monsanto-farmers-weed-problem-science-can-help/">
             superweeds
            </a>
            .
           </p>
           <figure aria-labelledby="figcaption_attachment_356247" class="wp-caption alignnone" id="attachment_356247" style="max-width: 610px">
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/pesticide.jpg">
             <span class="image-container wp-image-356247 size-full" style="max-width:600px;max-height:401px;">
              <img alt="pesticide" class="wp-image-356247 size-full" height="401" src="//ecowatch.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/pesticide.jpg" width="600"/>
             </span>
            </a>
            <figcaption class="wp-caption-text" id="figcaption_attachment_356247">
             Farmers of commodity crops like soy and corn, which tend to be genetically modified, use herbicides like Roundup more or less indiscriminately, says Andy Dyer, a guest on yesterdays show.
             <a href="http://www.shutterstock.com/pic-211165576/stock-photo-tractor-spraying-pesticides-on-a-field.html?src=ULTf5Kx9nKYZFb5q9fmddg-1-8&amp;ws=0" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'http://www.shutterstock.com/pic-211165576/stock-photo-tractor-spraying-pesticides-on-a-field.html?src=ULTf5Kx9nKYZFb5q9fmddg-1-8&amp;ws=0', 'Photo credit: Shutterstock');">
              Photo credit: Shutterstock
             </a>
            </figcaption>
           </figure>
           <p>
            This new herbicide has many in the environmental and health communities concerned because of the
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/2015/01/23/health-problems-linked-to-monsanto-roundup/">
             dangerousimpacts to human health
            </a>
            and the
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/2014/02/27/monsantos-roundup-found-in-75-of-air-and-rain-samples/">
             environment
            </a>
            . The
            <a href="http://www.nrdc.org/" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'http://www.nrdc.org/', 'Natural Resources Defense Council');" target="_blank">
             Natural Resources Defense Council
            </a>
            (NRDC) and other groups sued to block the EPAs approval because they dont think the EPA considered all of the environmental and health impacts of the new herbicide.Many have joined the NRDC incalling for a
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/2014/09/29/gmo-crops-accelerate-herbicide-insecticide/">
             new approach to pest and weed control
            </a>
            that doesnt wreak havoc on
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/living/health-stories/">
             human health
            </a>
            and the environment.
           </p>
           <p>
            Rehm starts the discussion by talking about the most common herbicide, Monsantos Roundup, which she says, is steadily becoming less effective. Erik Olson, director of the health program for the NRDC explains why that is:
           </p>
           <div class="unit" id="div-gpt-ad-1433512244421-0" style="height:90px; width:728px;margin-bottom:14px;">
            <script type="text/javascript">
             googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display("div-gpt-ad-1433512244421-0"); });
            </script>
           </div>
           <p style="padding-left: 30px;">
            What we have is a chemical arms race between the pesticide companies, who are developing ever more powerful pesticides to kill bugs and to kill weeds, and the bugs and weeds that keep evolving and become more resistant to those pesticides. So another new generation of pesticides have to be invented. So were on this treadmill.
           </p>
           <p>
            During the process of deploying more and more pesticides to deal with pests and weeds that are resistant, we are killing non-target organisms, according to Olson. Thesenon-target organisms are often
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/2014/05/06/spiders-in-your-garden/">
             beneficial insects
            </a>
            
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/2014/10/29/flupyradifurone-bad-news-bees/">
             bees in particular
            </a>
            that help keep pest populations in check and pollinate crops.
           </p>
           <p>
            How do these pests and weeds become resistant? Its basic evolution, says Olson. A pesticide can wipe out 99.9 percent of pests or weeds but that 0.1 percent that survives is resistant and they produce offspring that are even more resistant, according to Olson.
           </p>
           <p>
            Thats why experts like Andy Dyer, professor of biology at the University of South Carolina,author of
            <em>
             Chasing the Red Queen: The Evolutionary Race Between Agricultural Pests and Poisons
            </em>
            and a guest onyesterdays show,say
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/2014/05/23/food-systems-affect-biodiversity/">
             gigantic monocultures
            </a>
            one single crop in a fieldare a huge problem. Wevetaken highly diversified ecosystems and reduced them to a single species, providing pests with an all-you-can-eat buffet, according to Dyer.
           </p>
           <p>
            Dyer says he wrotehisbook becausethe connection between pesticide resistance and the underlying principles of evolutionary biologywhile theyre understoodhave not really been closely linked. Dyer says, we have to realize each chemical pesticide has a lifespan and it will lose its effectiveness over time.
           </p>
           <p>
            Les Glasgow of Syngentasaid on yesterdays showthat because herbicides like Roundup are so effective in the short term, they get overused to the point where theylose their effectiveness. The future really is about diversity for weed management, says Glasgow. If we can introduce more diversity in the tactics that we use for weed control, then we can certainly avoid the resistance. Glasgow says products like Roundup and now Enlist Duo are not intended to be used on their own.
           </p>
           <p>
            Thats not common practice, though. Farmers of commodity crops like soy and corn, which tend to be
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/news/food-agriculture/gmo-genetically-modified-organism/">
             genetically modified
            </a>
            , use herbicides like Roundup more or less indiscriminately because its their one tool in pest and weed control, says Dyer.
           </p>
           <p>
            Aaron Hobbs, president of Responsible Industryfor a Sound Environment,says pesticides are merely a part of the solution. He calls for integrated pest management, which is an approach to controlling pests that relies on a combination of best practices. Hobbs agrees with the other guests that weve completely overused Roundup, dousing fields with it and as a result weve killed off a lot of the milkweed, a plant that Monarch butterflies feed on. With milkweed wiped out, the
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/2014/01/30/monsanto-culprit-record-decline-monarch-butterflies/">
             Monarch butterfly population has collapsed
            </a>
            as well. The increased reliance on chemical pesticides is effecting the entire food web.
           </p>
           <p>
            Not only are these chemical pesticides destroying human health and the environment, but, according to Olson, it can cost millions of dollars to develop a new pesticide, and yet they can become obsolete within a few years. So we need to work with nature using these more innovative tools of
            <a href="http://ecowatch.com/2015/01/06/regenerative-organic-agriculture/">
             sustainable agriculture
            </a>
            , Olson says.
           </p>
           <p>
            Allen, a listener whocalled into the show is a former EPA employee, says 2,4-D should have been phased out years ago. It was half of agent orange and its just being brought back and its a really bad idea.Olson and Dyer agree were on a backwards trend:were using dangerous chemicals on fewer and fewer crops with less and less genetic diversity. We need a wide variety of crops with high genetic diversity in order to move away from this chemical dependency. Olson says, I think we can all agree in this room that taking an integrated approach to solve a pest problem is the way to go.
           </p>
           <p>
            Listen to the full discussionon
            <a href="http://thedianerehmshow.org/shows/2015-02-03/environmental_outlook_the_race_against_pests_and_weeds" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-article', 'http://thedianerehmshow.org/shows/2015-02-03/environmental_outlook_the_race_against_pests_and_weeds', 'The Diane Rhem Show');" target="_blank">
             The Diane Rhem Show
            </a>
            .
           </p>
           <p>
            <strong>
             YOU MIGHT ALSO LIKE
            </strong>
           </p>
           <p>
            <span style="color: #008000;">
             <a class="gs-title" data-ctorig="http://ecowatch.com/2015/01/06/regenerative-organic-agriculture/" data-cturl="https://www.google.com/url?q=http://ecowatch.com/2015/01/06/regenerative-organic-agriculture/&amp;sa=U&amp;ei=O1XSVNOuKs6zyATuxoCoBg&amp;ved=0CBUQFjAI&amp;client=internal-uds-cse&amp;usg=AFQjCNEVnFvQVS7msNdlWsZi14fmgQZlGw" dir="ltr" href="http://ecowatch.com/2015/01/06/regenerative-organic-agriculture/" style="color: #008000;" target="_blank">
              The Solution Under Our Feet: How Regenerative Organic Agriculture Can Save the Planet
             </a>
            </span>
           </p>
           <p class="title">
            <span style="color: #008000;">

             </a>
            </span>
           </p>

           </p>
          </div>

                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-154909">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-154909">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-154909">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-154909">
                          NoToGMOs
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-154909">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-154909">
                         <p>
                          If you knew anything about science you would know that in order to study most aspects of a substance, it is best to study it in the context that it is produced in or exists in nature. Using
                          <b>
                           bacterial
                          </b>
                          Bt toxin to determine the LD50 (and other effects) of the
                          <b>
                           plant-produced
                          </b>
                          GMO Bt was a ruse thought up by the industry in cahoots with the regulatory agencies to fool the public into thinking that the plant Bt has been well-studied and is safe..so that they could fast-track their invention on to an unsuspecting public.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-154916">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-154916">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-154916">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-154916">
                          Arthur Doucette
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-154916">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-154916">
                         <p>
                          Youve got it totally BACKWARD.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The Organic version contains 54% of the Bacteria Spores, Fermentation Solids and Toxins.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The Toxins are the Cry Proteins. (different strains of bacteria produce different Cry proteins of which there are many: Cry1Aa, Cry1Ab, Cry2Aa, Cry3Aa, Cry3Bb, Cry4Aa, Cry4Bb and Cyt2A.)
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          So the LD50 for Dipel is for the entire formulations (half of which is not disclosed because it is a trade secret).
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.valent.com/Data/Labels/2014-DDF-0001%20DiPel%20DF%20-%20form%2004-7783-R11.pdf" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'download', 'http://www.valent.com/Data/Labels/2014-DDF-0001%20DiPel%20DF%20-%20form%2004-7783-R11.pdf');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.valent.com/Data/Labels/2014-DDF-0001%20DiPel%20DF%20-%20form%2004-7783-R11.pdf
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.valent.com/Data/Labels/BIO-0022rev4.pdf" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'download', 'http://www.valent.com/Data/Labels/BIO-0022rev4.pdf');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.valent.com/Data/Labels/BIO-0022rev4.pdf
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          In contrast, the GMO plants currently in use ONLY express one specific Cry Protein, so you can in fact isolate that protein and use it in acute toxicity studies (that way you can feed far more of the protein to an animal than it could possibly consume by eating the grain).
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          For instance Cry1A(b)  is only a small portion of MON809 plant protein. In MON809, Cry1A(b) makes up 1.63, 0.55, and 1.23 g/g of leaf, grain, and whole plant tissue, respectively.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          So what we eat is the grain, which is but 0.55 g/g.
                          <br/>
                          There are 28 grams in an ounce.
                          <br/>
                          Say you eat a pound of corn, thats 448 grams, or 25 g or 0.25 mg
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Which is why feeding trials of just the protein are more effective at showing no impact, regardless of how much you eat since they have done mouse studies fed at the rate of 5,000 mg/kg with no ill effects.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-155152">
                       <p>
                        First of all Bt is not produced by plants unless it has been introduced into the plant to do so. And actually the Bt used in GMO crops is the same as that found in the soil. And the LD50 of the Bt toxin in GMO crops is the same has that found in the soil. Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) is an insecticide with unusual properties that make it useful for pest control in certain situations. Bt is a naturally occurring bacterium common in soils throughout the world. Several strains can infect and kill insects. Because of this property, Bt has been developed for insect control. At present, Bt is the only microbial insecticide in widespread use.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>

                     <p>
                      You have to love when they say things like, Glyphosate is 50 times less toxic than Atrazine, the product it replaced.
                      <br/>
                      According to the EPA in 1993(before GMO crops)
                      <br/>
                      Atrazine use was between 70 and 75 million pounds.
                      <br/>
                      Glyphosate use was between 15 and 20 million pounds.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      According to the EPA in 2007(after GMO crops)
                      <br/>
                      Atrazine use was between 73 and 78 million pounds.
                      <br/>
                      Glyphosate use was between 180 and 185 million pounds.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Obvious FarmersSon63 is really bad at math since Atrazine use has increased a few million pounds and Glyphosate use has increased over 160 million pounds since the introduction of GMO crops.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      I guess when they have no argument they just make one up and hope nobody notices.

                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153020">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153020">

                         <p>
                          Do you have evidence that the data I provided is not factual?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          According to the EPA in 1993(before GMO crops)
                          <br/>
                          Atrazine use was between 70 and 75 million pounds.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Glyphosate use was between 15 and 20 million pounds.
                          <br/>
                          Page 14,
                          <a href="http://www.epa.gov/pesticides/pestsales/99pestsales/market_estimates1999.pdf" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'download', 'http://www.epa.gov/pesticides/pestsales/99pestsales/market_estimates1999.pdf');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.epa.gov/pesticides/pestsales/99pestsales/market_estimates1999.pdf
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          According to the EPA in 2007(after GMO crops)
                          <br/>
                          Atrazine use was between 73 and 78 million pounds.
                          <br/>
                          Glyphosate use was between 180 and 185 million pounds.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Table 3.6
                          <br/>
                          <a href="http://www.epa.gov/opp00001/pestsales/07pestsales/usage2007_2.htm" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.epa.gov/opp00001/pestsales/07pestsales/usage2007_2.htm', 'http://www.epa.gov/opp00001/pestsales/07pestsales/usage2007_2.htm');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.epa.gov/opp00001/pestsales/07pestsales/usage2007_2.htm
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          You think your source is unbiased?  Your reference is to a website run by a biased genetic engineer, two of her students and a guy who runs another website with a guy who conducts seminars for Monsanto.  LOL!  Looks like about more than half of the references on that list were conducted, contracted or funded by biotech companies or affiliates and you think that is unbiased?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          I guess when they have no argument they just make one up and hope nobody notices.
                         </p>
                        </div>

                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153073">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153073">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153073">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153073">
                          No Gmo
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153073">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153073">
                         <p>
                          LOL!  You dont know any of this?  Ill give you several studies, but after that Im done wasting time on an anti-science flatearther such as yourself.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Moreover, it was demonstrated that environmentally relevant concentrations of Roundup can pose a health risk for fish populations.
                          <a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20643706" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20643706', 'http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20643706');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20643706
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Fishes were exposed to herbicide at a dose of 4 mgl-1 generally used by farmers to control weedsSevere damage, shrinkage and degeneration of pentagonal cellular contour of stratified epithelial cells (SEC) were observed in gill. Shrinkage of SEC resulting in degeneration of microridges was observed in buccopharynx. Slight necrosed and distorted SEC was observed in oesophagus. Severe mucus secretion was observed in stomach. Erosion on the apical surface of mucosal folds and columnar epithelial cells (CEC) and necrosis of CEC was also noticed in stomach. 
                          <a href="http://www.cabdirect.org/abstracts/20093248244.html;jsessionid=7058798D204C4F4BD05B455F1F4B2FA5" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.cabdirect.org/abstracts/20093248244.html;jsessionid=7058798D204C4F4BD05B455F1F4B2FA5', 'http://www.cabdirect.org/abstracts/20093248244.html;jsessionid=7058798D204C4F4BD05B455F1F4B2FA5');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.cabdirect.org/abstracts/20093248244.html;jsessionid=7058798D204C4F4BD05B455F1F4B2FA5
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          These results indicate that AChE-a neurotoxicity biomarker-in C. decemmaculatus may be affected by exposure to environmentally relevant concentrations of glyphosate.
                          <a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22002176" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22002176', 'http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22002176');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22002176
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The objective of the present study was to evaluate the genotoxic potential of Roundup to blood and liver cells in the Neotropical fish Corydoras paleatus  (Jenyns 1842) following short term exposure (3, 6, and 9 days) to an environmentally realistic concentration of the herbicide (6.67 ug/L Roundup).We conclude that for the low concentration used in this research, the herbicide shows potential genotoxic effects.
                          <a href="http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10661-012-2783-x" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10661-012-2783-x', 'http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10661-012-2783-x');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10661-012-2783-x
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          I can give you a hundred more without really even trying, but that would just be a huge waste of time on an anti-science flatearther.  If you really want more just go to the NTO section here.
                          <a href="http://www.gmofreeusa.org/research/glyphosate/glyphosate-studies/" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.gmofreeusa.org/research/glyphosate/glyphosate-studies/', 'http://www.gmofreeusa.org/research/glyphosate/glyphosate-studies/');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.gmofreeusa.org/research/glyphosate/glyphosate-studies/
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Thanks for the laughs, and good luck with that whole not falling off the Earth thing.  LOL!
                         </p>

                          Fishes were exposed to herbicide at a dose of 4 mgl-1 generally used by farmers to control weeds
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          4 mg/l exposure?  Thats interesting, since USGS survey data shows waterway glyphosate concentrations less than 10 ug/l.  Im having a hard time seeing how a study that exposes fish to a RoundUp concentration 400 times greater than found in situ is relevant.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Moreover, it was demonstrated that environmentally relevant concentrations of Roundup can pose a health risk for fish populations.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          And that study used concentrations of 58 and 116 ug/l, which is 6 to 12 times the concentration found in situ.  How is that relevant?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          These results indicate that AChE-a neurotoxicity biomarker-in C. decemmaculatus may be affected by exposure to environmentally relevant concentrations of glyphosate.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          And that studys lowest glyphosate concentration was 1 mg/l, which is 100 times the glyphosate levels found in situ.  How is that relevant?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Im beginning to think that you dont really understand what you are linking to.
                         </p>

                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153161">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-153161">

                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-153005">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153005">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-153005">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-153005">
                    TZ
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153005">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153005">
                   <p>
                    <a href="http://www.i-sis.org.uk/Glyphosate_Toxic_to_Mouth_Cells.php" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.i-sis.org.uk/Glyphosate_Toxic_to_Mouth_Cells.php', 'http://www.i-sis.org.uk/Glyphosate_Toxic_to_Mouth_Cells.php');" rel="nofollow">
                     http://www.i-sis.org.uk/Glyphosate_Toxic_to_Mouth_Cells.php
                    </a>
                    <br/>
                    New research finds that glyphosate causes cell and DNA damage to epithelial cells derived from the inside of the mouth and throat [1]. It raises concerns over the safety of inhaling glyphosate, one of the most common ways in which people are exposed to the herbicide.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Siegfried Knasmueller and his colleagues the Medical University of Vienna, Austria, found that Monsantos formulated version of glyphosate called Roundup Ultra Max caused cellular damage and DNA damage including chromosomal abnormalities and ultimately killed the cells at higher concentrations. Importantly, DNA damage occurred at concentrations below those required to induce cell damage, suggesting that the DNA damage was caused directly by glyphosate instead of being an indirect result of cell toxicity.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    These are not the first findings of glyphosate-based herbicides cytotoxic and genotoxic effects. Numerous independent research teams have been documenting the hazards of glyphosate exposure over the last few years with in vivo, in vitro and clinical studies.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    DNA damage was observed in blood samples from exposed residents in Argentina and Ecuador [2, 3]. Lab mice were found to harbour chromosomal and DNA damage in bone marrow, liver and kidney cells as well as lymphoid cells [4]. Similar effects were found in non-mammalian species, including sea urchins [5], goldfish [6, 7], eels [8], tilapia fish [9] as well as the fruitfly [10]. These experiments show that glyphosate herbicides are dangerous for humans and many other animals. Glyphosate is highly soluble in water, so impacts on aquatic wildlife may be of particular concern, especially following the recent report on the presence of glyphosate in rain water, groundwater, rivers and air [11, 12]. Its extreme toxic effects on amphibians such as frogs has already been shown (see [13] Roundup Kills Frogs, SiS 26). Cell damage has been documented in many cell types including those derived from the rat testis (see [14] Glyphosate Kills Rat Testes Cells, SiS 54), human placenta, umbilical cord, and embryo (see [15] Death by Multiple Poisoning, Glyphosate and Roundup, SiS 42), rat and carp neurones [16, 17], and liver [18, 19].
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-153078">

                      patiently waiting for your information.

                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-153409">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153409">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-153409">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-153409">
                        Arthur Doucette
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153409">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153409">
                       <p>
                        In what way is our civilization collapsing?
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Death rates in 2012 continued to decline among most groups defined by sex, race, and Hispanic origin. Although changes in mortality are relatively small from one year to the next, long-term trends show the apparent progress in reducing mortality. For example, the age-adjusted death rate in the US decreased 15.7% from 869.0 to 732.8 deaths per 100,000 standard population from 2000 to 2012.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        <a href="http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/283625.php" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/283625.php', 'http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/283625.php');" rel="nofollow">
                         http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/283625.php
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Life Expectancy
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Year Both Male Female Increase
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        2012  78.8  76.4  81.2
                        <br/>
                        2010  78.7  76.2  81.1  1.2%
                        <br/>
                        2005  77.8  75.2  80.4  1.0%
                        <br/>
                        2000  77.0  74.3  79.7  1.6%
                        <br/>
                        1995  75.8  72.5  78.9  0.5%
                        <br/>
                        1990  75.4  71.8  78.8  0.9%
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        <a href="http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0111629" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0111629', 'http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0111629');" rel="nofollow">
                         http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0111629
                        </a>
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Results: On average, GM technology adoption has reduced chemical pesticide use by 37%, increased crop yields by 22%, and increased farmer profits by 68%. Yield gains and pesticide reductions are larger for insect-resistant crops than for herbicide-tolerant crops. Yield and profit gains are higher in developing countries than in developed countries.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153412">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153412">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153412">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153412">
                          Vera Gottlieb
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153412">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153412">
                         <p>
                          Nature worked for thousands of years without man-produced chemicals. Now mankind, for the sake of some worthless dollars, is interfering and this just cant end well. Too bad birds and butterflies and bees cant talkthey are suffering plenty on account of chemicals and GMOs.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153457">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153457">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153457">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153457">
                          Arthur Doucette
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153457">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153457">
                         <p>
                          You dont think it has more to do with the 7+ billion of us?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Why do you blame it on the farmers?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Farmers are producing FAR more food on the SAME amount of land.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          If they werent using these techniques they would be cutting down forests like crazy, but they arent. The amount of forest land in the US is the same today as it was 100 years ago.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The UN also reports that there were 1 billion hungry people in 1990-92 and and the world population was 5.4 Billion, thus 18% were hungry (and many were actually starving).
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Today while there remain 870 million hungry, divided by 2013 world population of 7.1 Billion is but 12% and starvation has been virtually eliminated.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          This represents a HUGE reduction in hunger in a short period of time while the words population has SOARED.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Why?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Because improved agricultural methods, adopted throughout the developing world has allowed agriculture to produce 17 percent more calories per person today than it did 30 years ago, despite a 70 percent population increase. A small
                          <br/>
                          percent of that is because of GMO. Over this coming decade, the value of GMO will only grow as crops like Golden Rice and Banana become adopted in areas were lack of Vitamin A still causes millions of children to die or go blind.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153776">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153776">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153776">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153776">
                          Mike S.
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153776">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153776">

                         </p>

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153682">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153682">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153682">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153682">
                          Mike S.
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153682">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153682">
                         <p>
                          Abstract: Glyphosate, the active ingredient in Roundup, is the most popular herbicide used worldwide. The industry asserts it is minimally toxic to humans, but here we argue otherwise. Residues are found in the main foods of the Western diet, comprised primarily of sugar, corn, soy and wheat. Glyphosates inhibition of cytochrome P450 (CYP) enzymes is an overlooked component of its toxicity to mammals. CYP enzymes play crucial roles in biology, one of which is to detoxify xenobiotics. Thus, glyphosate enhances the damaging effects of other food borne chemical residues and environmental toxins. Negative impact on the body is insidious and manifests slowly over time as inflammation damages cellular systems throughout the body. Here, we show how interference with CYP enzymes acts synergistically with disruption of the biosynthesis of aromatic amino acids by gut bacteria, as well as impairment in serum sulfate transport. Consequences are most of the diseases and conditions associated with a Western diet, which include gastrointestinal disorders, obesity, diabetes, heart disease, depression, autism, infertility, cancer and Alzheimers disease. We explain the documented effects of glyphosate and its ability to induce disease, and we show that glyphosate is the textbook example of exogenous semiotic entropy: the disruption of homeostasis by environmental toxins.  *entropy
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-154886">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-154886">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-154886">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-154886">
                          Arthur Doucette
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-154886">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-154886">
                         <p>
                          Essentially Organic and GMO crops dont compete.
                          <br/>
                          The majority of our Organic crops are Vegetables, Fruit, Berries and Nuts. Which only compete with a small amount of GMO sweet corn, squash and Papaya
                          <br/>
                          Almost all of our GMO is Corn, Soybeans, Sugar Beets, Canola and Cotton.
                          <br/>
                          What isnt GMO is almost all conventional for those crops.
                          <br/>
                          The biggest organic grains are Wheat and Oats, and they arent GMO.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          So if you are an Organic grower, typically you arent competing with GMO at all but with conventional growers. In most cases your yields will be lower (~20 or so percent) but the higher price you get for Organic produce will usually make up for your lower yields and higher labor costs per acre.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153546">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153546">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153546">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153546">
                          hyperzombie
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153546">

                         <p>
                          <i>
                           Nutrients are way more important than calories.
                          </i>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Yeah sure, try living on nutrients alone. If you fertilize a plant can it live in the dark? Calories are energy.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <i>
                           What is the nutritional value difference in GMO and organically grown?
                          </i>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Nothing.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <i>
                           Not only in the food, but the soil and the bugs around it?
                          </i>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Depends what you are growing, but more often than not, once again nothing is different.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <i>
                           How would we continue to feed 9+ billion people if we push all the bugs out?
                          </i>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          All farming methods try to eliminate harmful insects, because they eat the crops and damage the plants.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <i>
                           This method is satanic!
                          </i>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Farmers have been using insecticides on crops for over 1000 years now, get a grip on reality.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153598">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153598">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153598">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153598">
                          hyperzombie
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153598">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153598">
                         <p>
                          <i>
                           I completely disagree with you.
                          </i>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Why, you should know this from nutrition classes in jr high school?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <i>
                           Nutrients are more important
                          </i>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Nope, calories are energy that you body needs to metabolize nutrients. Without energy your body will die, try living on vitamins.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/263028.php" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/263028.php', 'http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/263028.php');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/263028.php
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <i>
                           There is a difference in GMO and non GMO nutritional values.
                          </i>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          THere are 4 meta studies on this, 3 say no difference, one says a slight difference, mostly more fat and less fiber.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <i>
                           Look it up. GMO depletes nutrients and deters vital insects and weeds.
                          </i>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          I think you need to look up what GMOs actually do, GMOs allow farmers NOT to spray insecticides, leaving all the beneficial insects intact. There are no vital weeds in Agriculture, all farmers kill weeds even organic ones.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <i>
                           Its satanic because its for profit not the healthiest foods in the world
                          </i>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Wouldnt the Organic folk be the Profit seekers? They are selling you the same food for 2x more moneyTalk about profit
                         </p>
                        </div>

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153757">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153757">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153757">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153757">
                          JoeFarmer
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153757">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153757">
                         <p>
                          You do realize that forage crops are intended for livestock, right?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Are you familiar with alfalfa?  Great for livestock, not so great in your salad.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          And there are lots of things like BMR corn (aka corn silage) where a farmer grows corn but harvests it before the ears fully develop.  Its for livestock feed, most usually for cattle, especially dairy herds.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          And theres haylage, wheatlage and a whole bunch of other crops that are intended for livestock and not the peeps.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          It really sounds like you should get out and actually meet a farmer and find out what he/she does for a living.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153769">

                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153769">
                          JoeFarmer
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153769">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153769">
                         <p>
                          Great!  I have no idea where you live, and I dont really care to know, but within about 20-25 miles from any major city, theres a modern farming operation.  Maybe you could check with your local university or community college to see where there are farms that you could visit.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Ill guarantee youd learn a lot.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          If youre not able to actually visit a farm, there are a lot of great ag universities like Iowa State, Purdue, Cornell, UC Davis, etc. that you can get a lot of great info from.  Plus, they are taxpayer funded, so you might as well learn something from them, right?
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>

                         </p>

                         </p>

                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153817">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153817">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153817">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153817">
                          JoeFarmer
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153817">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153817">
                         <p>
                          Intercropping is an interesting concept.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Im assuming that the intercrop is sacrificial, since a fully-canopied corn crop uses up 95-96% of the available light.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          There are mechanical issues, like how do you plant two dissimilar crops.  And how does the intercrop compete with the cash crop for nutrients and water.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          My thought from reading research so far is that the weed suppression potential from intercropping is given up by what Ive mentioned above.  Im always open to research links, though.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153862">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153862">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153862">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153862">
                          Eric Bjerregaard
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153862">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153862">
                         <p>
                          Hi Joe, I think Rob Wallbridge posted an article about a guy that was planting 2 crops in groups of rows, that his equipment could straddle and had modified his equipment accordingly. so, the shade was not an issue as the groups of rows gave the shorter plants enough sun. I dont grow that way. Grow pineapples, and rotational crops in greenhouses. So while interested. did not really learn it. Rob is organic and writes for biofortified and you can contact y finding one of his articles and commenting to him.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153866">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153866">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153866">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153866">
                          JoeFarmer
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153866">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153866">
                         <p>
                          All I can tell you is that corn will completely canopy over by about V12 stage, maybe V10.  By that time any intercrop will be starved of light.  Which is why I made the specific point that a fully developed corn crop will absorb 95-96% of available light.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          I dont know what else I can can tell you.  I am always open to new information though.
                         </p>
                        </div>

                          Hi Joe, Most native soils do not drain well enough to use as potting soils and weigh too much as well. I grow some ornamentals, and for disease and nematode reasons some of my veggies in large containers. Okra in particular is susceptible to nematodes.

                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153868">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153868">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153868">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153868">
                          Eric Bjerregaard
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153868">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153868">
                         <p>
                          Maybe this is a southern thing. But most everyone down here starts seedlings in greenhouses before frost date, and then sets out transplants just after the date. Helps get a jump on getting a crop in before the rain, heat and humidity set in. And gives the root systems a headstart on soil born diseases. Especially damping off. Though I still get damp off in my papayas, especially if I run them a bit wet and we get cloudy and cold in Jan. People think we have a real long season. That is only partially correct. When the rains start, usually in June. The melons, tomatoes, and others crack and split from the unneeded water, and the fungal and bacterial problems can get bad.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

This epic run of pollution can be counted as the worst in the history of this country.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Despite this, Monsanto has arranged not only to survive, but even to thrive, maintaining strong ties inside in the US government (especially the FDA). The corporation wages widespread campaigns of misinformation, persecuting institutions and individuals, including scientists, farmers and activists that dare to disclose these crimes. Today, Monsanto is addressing a new chapter in its history of successful failures, through the creation and commercialization of Genetically Modified Organism or GMOs. Monsanto continues to spread new technologies and products which are ringing alarms among scientific, human rights and ecological organizations around the globe for concerns over public health, food safety and ecological sustainability
                         </p>

                         <p>
                          Mike, the answers to your 1st and 2nd question are the same it about promoting   GMO crops thru out the world. The GMO rice is called GoldenRice as it is grown using traits of GMO corn which contain beta-carotene.  Rice is the largest crop grown in the far east. The development of this rice was funded by the Rockefellas and Bill Gates in conjunction with Sygenta. It was tested in the Phillipines and local farmers pulled it out of the ground by it roots. You would need to eat eat 20 bowls of rice per day for your rda of vitamin A. The Rockafellas stopped  their funding. As far as the gmo bananas they are grown using green pepper traits. The last I heard these were tested on some college kids in Iowa. Uganda is slated to put these bananas into production in 4 or 5 years. Many experts say providing vitamin A supplements is way more effective and much less expensive. But as we all know from history the 3rd world countries have and are being raped of their natural resources and the majority of their people kept in absolute poverty.

                         <p>
                          Right, farmers have eradicated a pesky weed and secondly, our demand for Ethanol for our cars has caused us to grow ever more corn, but the problem is NOT that glyphosate is to blame, but because weeds and agriculture dont mix. Even Organic farmers would keep milkweed in check.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          All that is needed is to proactively plant milkweed in non farm areas, and we have no shortage of those. Talk to your local city council and just get it done.
                         </p>

                         </p>

                          Claiming that its food vs. fuel just isnt the case.
                         </p>

                          Not happening.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Death rates in 2012 continued to decline among most groups defined by sex, race, and Hispanic origin. Although changes in mortality are relatively small from one year to the next, long-term trends show the apparent progress in reducing mortality. For example, the age-adjusted death rate in the US decreased 15.7% from 869.0 to 732.8 deaths per 100,000 standard population from 2000 to 2012.
                         </p>
                        </div>

                          She wasnt talking about death rates Arthur and you know it.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The nations largest health care organization sent a newsletter to their patients. In that newsletter was An article by one of their nutritionists who explained GMOs and then told the patients to avoid them so as to not degrade their health. The health care organization had no official policy on Roundup laden GMOs because of the politics, but it cared enough about the concerns of its medical staff, its patients, and its bottom line to send out the warning
                          <br/>
                          <a href="http://www.willamettelive.com/2012/news/corporate-giant-comes-out-against-gmos/" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.willamettelive.com/2012/news/corporate-giant-comes-out-against-gmos/', 'http://www.willamettelive.com/2012/news/corporate-giant-comes-out-against-gmos/');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.willamettelive.com/2012/news/corporate-giant-comes-out-against-gmos/
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          There have been no long term independent studies of the health effects of Roundup laden GMOs on human health. Many health care organizations are recognizing that severe unexplainable symptoms that are being reported by their patients get better when Roundup laden GMOs are removed from their diet.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>

                   <p>
                    The boomer generation has witnessed the population double in their lifetime.  In year 2000 the population hit 6 billion.  The population is now above 7 billion.  We are exponentially growing and 9 billion is not far off.  When the American Indians were farming the land there were a lot less people.  In order to survive the population, they relied on artificial selection to increase their crop yields and get the largest foods. Maize -&gt; corn is a common example.  Dont think that they had it all figured out, no generation has.  Its a daunting task to feed large populations of people.
                   </p>

                       <p>
                        Thats NOT what the report claims:
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        The world produces enough food to feed everyone. World agriculture produces 17 percent more calories per person today than it did 30 years ago, despite a 70 percent population increase. This is enough to provide everyone in the world with at least 2,720 kilocalories (kcal) per person per day  according to the most recent estimate that we could find (FAO 2002, p.9).  The principal problem is that many people in the world do not have sufficient land to grow, or income to purchase, enough food.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        POVERTY leads to HUNGER
                       </p>

                          They naturally eat vegetation.
                          <br/>
                          They get fed SILAGE which is the corn stalks as well as the corn, which is vegetation.
                          <br/>
                          They dont get sick from eating it or farmers wouldnt feed it to them.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->

                          No Rob, its not.
                          <br/>
                          We apply Glyphosate at the rate of about 1 lb per ACRE.
                          <br/>
                          Not including the end zones, thats ~ equal to the size of a football field.
                          <br/>
                          And we apply it at the START of the growing season for GMO crops.
                          <br/>
                          So by the END of the season, its nearly gone.
                         </p>

                         <p>
                          There have been no long term independent studies of the health effects of Roundup laden GMOs on human health.                          </p>
                         <p>
                          The nations largest health care organization sent a newsletter to their patients. In that newsletter was An article by one of their nutritionists who explained GMOs and then told the patients to avoid them so as to not degrade their health. The health care organization had no official policy on GMOs because of the politics, but it cared enough about the concerns of its medical staff, its patients, and its bottom line to send out the warning.
                          <br/>
                          <a href="http://www.willamettelive.com/2012/news/corporate-giant-comes-out-against-gmos/" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.willamettelive.com/2012/news/corporate-giant-comes-out-against-gmos/', 'http://www.willamettelive.com/2012/news/corporate-giant-comes-out-against-gmos/');" rel="nofollow">

                         </p>

                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-152862">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-152862">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-152862">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-152862">
                    mesmereyes
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-152862">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-152862">
                   <p>
                    Roundup is primarily used on Roundup-Ready GMO crops:  corn, soy, canola, cottonseed and sugar beet (almost all non-organic are now GMO).  Unfortunately, Roundup is also used as a drying agent on non-GMO crops such as wheat and legumes.  Not only is it environmentally destructive, it has been implicated in a host of chronic diseases.  It was only tested for safety for 90 days on lab rats by Monsanto, the equivalent of about 10 years in humans.  Many chronic disorders like cancer take longer than 10 years to appear.  Basically, were the guinea pigs.  Roundup has only been heavily used for the past 10 or 15 years, its increased use (in millions of lbs.) correlates almost exactly with the rise of chronic illnesses.  Of course, the paid commenters for Monsanto (typically using a homey farmer in their I.D.s) are correct in saying that correlation doesnt mean causation  this is how these companies side-step legal responsibility.  After 10 or 20 years its almost impossible to prove that your cancer was caused by years of eating Roundup-dosed products.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">

                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-152974">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-152974">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-152974">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-152974">
                        Tont Davies
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-152974">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-152974">
                       <p>

                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153004">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153004">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153004">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153004">
                          TZ
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153004">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153004">
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.i-sis.org.uk/DMPGR.php" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.i-sis.org.uk/DMPGR.php', 'http://www.i-sis.org.uk/DMPGR.php');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.i-sis.org.uk/DMPGR.php
                          </a>
                          <br/>
                          These latest studies confirm a wealth of evidence on the toxicities of glyphosate and Roundup formulations [2] ( Glyphosate Toxic &amp; Roundup Worse , SiS 26), and pinpoint the different sites of action, all of which result in cell death. Epidemiological studies have previously linked glyphosate to spontaneous abortions, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and multiple myeloma. Laboratory studies showed that glyphosate inhibits transcription in sea urchin eggs and delays development. Brief exposures to glyphosate in rats caused liver damage, and adding the surfactant in Roundup had a synergistic effect, causing greater liver damage. Roundup was also found to be much more lethal to frogs than to weeds, and could have contributed to the global demise of amphibians within the past decades [3] ( Roundup Kills Frogs , SiS 26).
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          We have called for a new regulatory review on glyphosate and Roundup in 2005 [2]. There is a now a strong case for restricting, if not phasing out glyphosate and Roundup; in the first instance, by banning the release of Roundup tolerant GM crops worldwide. For the same reason, no further Roundup tolerant GM crops should be approved for commercial release.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153393">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153393">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153393">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153393">
                          Arthur Doucette
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153393">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153393">
                         <p>
                          JoeFarmer, you just have to understand that you are dealing with people who arent concerned about the truth.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The USDA has always kept track of pesticide use by weight.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Because it is a good way of tracking the use of a SPECIFIC pesticide from year to year.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          These people though use it to compare use of pesticides whose weight of Active ingredient varies greatly by pesticide.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          We wouldnt ever hear of this except for the fact that the WEIGHT of glyphosate makes it one of the heaviest of herbicides.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Consider, on Corn, the average application of Glyphosate is 0.931 lbs per acre.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          But for MESOTRIONE, the average application was but 0.121 lbs per acre
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          or for ISOXAFLUTOLE the average application was but 0.066 lbs per acre
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/C4CBFDC5-84B7-351B-B840-60AE831F5859#858A5CFD-393D-3C8D-A020-8BBFA55F616B" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/C4CBFDC5-84B7-351B-B840-60AE831F5859#858A5CFD-393D-3C8D-A020-8BBFA55F616B', 'http://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/C4CBFDC5-84B7-351B-B840-60AE831F5859#858A5CFD-393D-3C8D-A020-8BBFA55F616B');" rel="nofollow">
