                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153186">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153186">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153186">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153186">
                          Arthur Doucette
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153186">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153186">
                         <p>
                          As to herbicides:
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Farmers are using more glyphosate because they are growing so many more crops tolerant of Glyphosate, but the amount PER ACRE hasnt been going up, and the amount of herbicide per acre hasnt been going up on an EIQ basis.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.ers.usda.gov/media/1141089/biotechcrops.png" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.ers.usda.gov/media/1141089/biotechcrops.png', 'http://www.ers.usda.gov/media/1141089/biotechcrops.png');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.ers.usda.gov/media/1141089/biotechcrops.png
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          This chart summarizes herbicide use on soybeans in 1996, before HT crops were widely adopted, and in 2006, after HT crops were widely adopted.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          For the column headings,
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Use = % of this pesticide compared to the total of all pesticides;
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Rate = pounds of active ingredient applied per acre of soybeans;
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Toxicity = chronic toxicity score (higher is safer);
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Half life = number of days it takes for 1/2 of the herbicide active ingredient to degrade in the soil.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          EIQ (Environmental Impact Quotient, lower is safer)  EIQ is a numerical representation of the risks a pesticide poses for the environment, consumers, and farm workers. (The EIQ for 2,4-D is an average of the EIQs for 5 different formulations of the herbicide.)
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          By 2006, the majority of farmers had switched to glyphosate, the least toxic of the herbicides, with it making up 85% of herbicide use. So the total amount of herbicides is trending down and the total environmental impact due to herbicides has also decreased.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.agbioforum.org/v15n3/v15n3a01-fernandez-cornejo.htm" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.agbioforum.org/v15n3/v15n3a01-fernandez-cornejo.htm', 'http://www.agbioforum.org/v15n3/v15n3a01-fernandez-cornejo.htm');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.agbioforum.org/v15n3/v15n3a01-fernandez-cornejo.htm
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://i0.wp.com/www.biofortified.org/wp-content/uploads//2014/02/Screen-Shot-2014-02-17-at-22.49.26.png?resize=325%2C226" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://i0.wp.com/www.biofortified.org/wp-content/uploads//2014/02/Screen-Shot-2014-02-17-at-22.49.26.png?resize=325%2C226', 'http://i0.wp.com/www.biofortified.org/wp-content/uploads//2014/02/Screen-Shot-2014-02-17-at-22.49.26.png?resize=325%2C226');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://i0.wp.com/www.biofortified.org/wp-content/uploads//2014/02/Screen-Shot-2014-02-17-at-22.49.26.png?resize=325%2C226
                          </a>
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

Between 1997 and 2007 there was about an 8% increase in Permanent cropland (% of land area) so that means if you were correct the new glyphosate use numbers in 2007 should be about  36.7 to 41 million pounds.  However, the EPA says glyphosate use in 2007 was between 180 and 185 million pounds.  So there is like 140 million pounds unaccounted for.  I guess you believe the glyphosate fairy is using it.

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-155093">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-155093">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-155093">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-155093">
                          TZ
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-155093">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-155093">
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://permaculturenews.org/2012/11/01/why-glyphosate-should-be-banned-a-review-of-its-hazards-to-health-and-the-environment/" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://permaculturenews.org/2012/11/01/why-glyphosate-should-be-banned-a-review-of-its-hazards-to-health-and-the-environment/', 'http://permaculturenews.org/2012/11/01/why-glyphosate-should-be-banned-a-review-of-its-hazards-to-health-and-the-environment/');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://permaculturenews.org/2012/11/01/why-glyphosate-should-be-banned-a-review-of-its-hazards-to-health-and-the-environment/
                          </a>
                          <br/>
                          There is a wealth of evidence on the health hazards of glyphosate. Its approval, along with other hazardous chemicals, relies on systematic flaws in the EU and US regulatory processes, which to this day, do not require evaluation by independent research, and instead rely solely on the industrys own studies. Approval is therefore often based on data not available to the public or independent research scientists. Nevertheless, raw data have been obtained from the industry through the law courts, which, when re-analysed by independent scientists, also provide evidence of toxicity.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Taken together, glyphosate is implicated in birth and reproductive defects, endocrine disruption, cancers, genotoxicity, neurotoxicity, respiratory problems, nausea, fever, allergies and skin problems.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-153155">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153155">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-153155">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-153155">
                    Loren Eaton
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153155">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153155">
                   <p>
                    Theres glyphosate in our food. This is indisputably causing health
                    <br/>
                    issues.  Really? Says who?
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-153306">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153306">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-153306">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-153306">
                      nick quinlan
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153306">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153306">
                     <p>
                      Not everyone agrees with this perception of glyphosates safety. The first Roundup resistant GMO crops, soybeans, were introduced by Monsanto in 1996. The same year, the first glyphosate resistant weeds began to emerge. Farmers responded by using increasingly toxic herbicides to deal with the new super weeds that had developed glyphosate resistance.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      In addition to the concern about the emergence of super weeds, a study in rats demonstrated that low levels of glyphosate induced severe hormone-dependent mammary, hepatic, and kidney disturbances. Recently two activist groups, Moms Across America and Thinking Moms Revolution, asked the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to recall Monsantos Roundup, citing a host of adverse health impacts in their children from the herbicide, including failure to thrive, leaky gut syndrome, autism and food allergies.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Glyphosate is no ordinary herbicide. Besides being the most used herbicide on earth, it is also the central pillar of Monsantos temple. Most of Monsantos seeds, including soy, corn, canola, alfalfa, cotton, sugar beets and sorghum, are glyphosate resistant. As of 2009, Monsantos Roundup (glyphosate) products, which include its GMO seeds, represented about half of Monsantos yearly revenue. This reliance on glyphosate products makes Monsanto extremely vulnerable to research challenging the herbicides safety.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Glyphosate-resistant seeds are engineered to allow the farmer to drench his fields in the herbicide to kill off all of the weeds. The glyphosate resistant crop can then be harvested. But if the combination of glyphosate and the heavy metals found in the groundwater or the soil destroys the farmers kidneys in the process, the whole house of cards falls apart. This may be what is happening now.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      An ugly confrontation has been unfolding in El Salvador. The US government has been pressuring El Salvador to buy GMO seeds from Monsanto rather than indigenous seeds from their own farmers. The US has threatened to withhold almost $300 million in aid unless El Salvador purchases Monsantos GMO seeds. The GMO seeds are more expensive. They are not adapted to the Salvadoran climate or soil.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      The only advantage of Monsantos GMO seeds is their glyphosate resistance. Now that glyphosate has been shown to be a possible, and perhaps likely, cause of  Chronic Kidney Disease, or CKDu, that advantage no longer exists
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      What is the message from the United States to El Salvador exactly? Perhaps the kindest explanation is that the United States is unaware that glyphosate may be the cause of the fatal kidney disease epidemic in El Salvador and that the government sincerely believes that the GMO seeds will provide a better yield. If so, a sad mixture of ignorance and arrogance is at the heart of this foreign policy blunder. A less kind interpretation would suggest that the government puts Monsantos profits above concerns about the economy, environment and health of the Salvadorans. This view would suggest that a tragic mix of greed and callous disregard for the Salvadorans is behind US policy.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Unfortunately, there is evidence to support the latter view. The United States seems to be completely behind Monsanto, regardless of any science questioning the safety of its products. Cables released by WikiLeaks show that US diplomats around the world are pushing GMO crops as a strategic government and commercial imperative. The cables also reveal instructions to punish any foreign countries trying to ban GMO crops.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-153378">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153378">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-153378">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-153378">
                        Arthur Doucette
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153378">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153378">
                       <p>
                        You wrote: Glyphosate-resistant seeds are engineered to allow the farmer to drench his fields in the herbicide to kill off all of the weeds. The glyphosate resistant crop can then be harvested.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Totally false: Glyphosate is applied at the rate of ~1 lb per acre or 16 ounces.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        There are 43,560 sq ft in an acre
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Thats but ONE OUNCE for an area that is 28 X 100
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        NOT DRENCHED
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        More importantly, glyphosate on GMO crops is applied at the START of the growing season, when the weeds are out (has to be applied to the leaves of the weeds to kill them), and this is MONTHS before harvest.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                     <ul class="children">

                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153485">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153485">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153485">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153485">
                          Arthur Doucette
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153485">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153485">
                         <p>
                          Nick, you are referring to PRE-HARVEST applications of glyphosate.
                          <br/>
                          This is done on a few crops, but NONE that are GMO.
                          <br/>
                          Why?
                          <br/>
                          Because glyphosate has no impact on GMO crops as they are immune to it and of course there is no value in killing weeds just before harvest.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          But glyphosate IS used on some NON-GMO crops in a pre harvest application, like Wheat, Potatoes and Carrots to dry them or kill off the green portions to make harvesting more efficient.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The reason they can do it at this time is that the wheat grain, tubers etc are essentially grown, and so while the green portions dry/die, their is little movement into the food portion of the plant.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                     </ul>
                     <!-- .children -->
                    </li>

                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-153268">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153268">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-153268">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-153268">
                    rick spalding
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153268">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153268">
                   <p>
                    organic farming done properly can be just as efficient as conventional, there is a 3 to 4 percent margin of error in there.  There is more than enough food on the planet for the current population.  Its a distribution problem, logistics.  The US alone wastes 40 percent of their food.  And china wastes even more on their imported food.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-153376">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153376">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-153376">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-153376">
                      Arthur Doucette
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153376">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153376">
                     <p>
                      Totally dependent on your definition of waste.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      For instance that high number starts with what is left in the field.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      But we cant economically harvest 100% of any crop.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      That number includes all packing, shipping and distribution losses, but they are already very efficient, still vegetables are perishable, so of course there are unavoidable losses along the way.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      That number includes all cooking scraps, as we prepare food to eat, but these are normal trimmings that we do, not what most people would consider waste (potato peels for example)
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      That number includes all weight loss from cooking, again not what people would consider waste.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      That number includes all table scraps we feed to our pets (any food not eaten by humans is considered waste)
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      That number includes all plate scraping, where there is too little to save, and from all restaurant meals.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      So no, we dont waste nearly as much food as you think we do, nor could we make it go down significantly
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      And finally Organic farming isnt nearly as productive as conventional Ag, particularly for our big Ag crops, Corn and Wheat.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Scientists from McGill University in Montreal, Canada and the University of Minnesota looked at 66 studies that compared yields of 34 crops grown using organic and conventional methods. They found that crop yields produced using organic methods can be up to 34 percent lower  than those produced using conventional techniques.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Organic farming practices appear to be particularly inefficient for grain and vegetable crops. The researchers suggest that lower yields are the result of the types of fertilizers that organic farmers use and how they use them.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      Organic yields were lower than conventional yields across the board, but the scientists found that organic methods could produce yields close to those of certain conventional crops, such as strawberries and soybeans.
                     </p>
                     <p>
                      There is still a big yield difference but the study does suggest organic systems have the potential to produce comparable yields, but in a very limited number of crops, Sonja Vermeulen, of the Copenhagen-based Consultative Group On International Agricultural Research, told Nature.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">

Meaning Round up does not reach the human food chain in such foods.   Our grandfathers use chemical that were much more harmful for the environment and their families, compared to what we use today.  Also the agricultural user of these chemical are trained and have to keep records on the application of these chemical where as the round up and other chemicals used by Joe public to maintain their lawn and or gardens/property dont have to be trained, keep records and account for every drop applied.  Think about that and then think why food is cheaper to buy here compared to overseas.  The American Farmer feeds more people per acre than any other area in the world.

                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153367">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153367">

                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153367">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153367">
                         <p>
                          What levels of glyphosate do you think actually exist in food?  You could look up the USDA PDP to find out, but I doubt you will, since its easier for you to just make stuff up.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          There are also plenty of studies about how glyphosate is metabolized.  But again, I doubt you will bother to read them since they would disrupt your faith-based beliefs.
                         </p>

                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-153022">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153022">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-153022">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-153022">
                      jrcsamad
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153022">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153022">
                     <p>
                      So many reports of how your Bosses poison is killing people
                      <br/>
                      Like the cigarette companies, Monsanto continues to defend Roundup  (Glyphosate) as safe to use, but accumulating scientific evidence shows  it could be among the most dangerous products on earth.
                      <br/>
                      The  worlds top selling herbicide is now implicated in a series of epidemics of fatal chronic kidney disease thats affecting poor farming regions  across the world, according to research published in the International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health.
                      <br/>
                      In Sri Lanka, 15% of the population is affected   400,000 patients and  20,000 deaths. Therefore, the president ordered that glyphosate be  banned a couple of weeks ago.
                      <br/>
                      An  investigation carried out by medical specialists and scientists reveals  that kidney disease is mainly caused by Glysophate. President Mahinda  Rajapaksa ordered the immediate removal of Glyphosate from the local  market soon after he heard of the contents of the report, S.M.  Chandrasena, Deputy Minister of Economic Development told reporters. He  said the 25,000 people currently fighting the disease would be assisted  with funds for  medical expenses and clean drinking water.
                      <br/>
                      The paper, Glyphosate, Hard Water and Nephrotoxic Metals: Are They the Culprits Behind the  Epidemic of Chronic Kidney Disease of Unknown Etiology in Sri Lanka?, suggests that a combination of  glyphosate in areas where there are heavy metals in the drinking water can lead to the disease.
                      <br/>
                      Glyphosate acts as a carrier or a vector of these heavy metals to the kidney,  explains Dr. Channa Jayasumana, the studys principal author.
                      <br/>
                      Metals like arsenic and cadmium can be present naturally in the soil or added  by spreading fertilizer. Heavy metals, glyphosate and other herbicides  have been found in urine samples of kidney patients, according to health officials there.
                      <br/>
                      This mysterious form of kidney disease has been  killing tens of thousands of agricultural workers in Central America,  Sri Lanka and India. Although it is completely treatable in wealthier  countries, more people have died from it in El Salvador and Nicaragua  than from diabetes, AIDS and leukemia combined over the last five years, reports Center for Public Integrity.
                      <br/>
                      El Salvador also passed  legislation to ban dozens of agrochemicals including glyphosate last  year, but it has yet to be signed into law.
                      <br/>
                      Watch these 5-minute documentaries, Mystery in the Fields and Cycle of Death for more information on this.
                      <br/>
                      Brazil, Chile Move Against Monsanto
                      <br/>
                      Action against glyphosate is also underway in Brazil, where the  Federal  Public Prosecutor is calling on the Justice Department to ban  it. Other GMO herbicides are also targets: 2,4-D and active ingredients methyl parathion, lactofem, phorate, carbofuran, abamectin, tiram and paraquat, according to GMWatch.
                      <br/>
                      Legal actions have been filed to compel Brazils National Health Surveillance Agency (ANVISA) to reevaluate the toxicity of those active  ingredients. The prosecutor wants the products banned until a final  conclusion is reached.
                      <br/>
                      The previous week, Brazils Federal Appeals Court unanimously ruled to cancel cultivation of Bayers Liberty Link GM Maize.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">

                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-153033">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153033">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-153033">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-153033">
                          jrcsamad
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153033">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153033">
                         <p>
                          The research study conducted by Dr. Channa Jayasumana of the Rajarata University found that while the weedicide itself is not nephrotoxic, when it combines with hard ground water containing metals such as cadmium and arsenic, either naturally present in the soil or added through fertilizer, glyphosate becomes extremely toxic to the kidney.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          However, since then the validity of Dr. Jayasumanas research had come under question as the manufacturer Monsanto and other agrochemical producers have raised objections to the findings saying that there is no evidence to suggest the conclusion that glyphosate is responsible for CKDu.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          A European glyphosate task force also has concluded that there is no true link to the kidney disease.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          GM Watch comment: As for the European glyphosate task force mentioned in the article, which has concluded that there is no true link between glyphosate herbicide and chronic kidney disease, lets hope the Sri Lankan government recognises that this task force is entirely made up of the pesticide companies that make and sell glyphosate herbicide!
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>

                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-154379">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-154379">
                         <p>
                          I would guess the way my likes are increasing exponentially and the only ones that you corporate crusading trolls are getting are by each other, that youre not going to convert a lot of people to your corporate funded ideology by dismissing those organizations as a clown car.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Those environmental &amp; consumer protection organizations educate people and they do use science, not just make things up like you imply they do. They expose corporate influence in the government by exposing where industry cronys came from and what they have done since they were placed their (usually regulatory) positions.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          They expose how industry makes up its own science and promotes it with PR companies, front groups and marketing campaigns (like you yourself and the other GMO cheerleaders swear you do it for free).
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Those environmental &amp; consumer protection organizations explain and give examples of how your beloved corporations try  to pretend things like Climate Change, Ocean Acidification, the Dead Zones in the oceans are all just hysterical liberals making up anything to cut into their profits. Those organizations also talk about solutions that might cut into your favourite corporations profits. They talk about advances in clean energy, health and pollution, contamination of our drinking water and how politicians that come from industry raise the levels of acceptable contaminants like lead,heavy metals and arsenic in our drinking water instead of holding the offending corporations accountable.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          They talk about daily exposure to Endocrine Disruptors like BPA, Dioxins, Atrazine, Pthalates and  Perchlorate and how lobbyists like the American Chemical Council (ACC) fight to prevent them from being taken off the market with their bogus science. So please spare us your industry funded agenda. We see it every day from you and your ilk.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-154888">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-154888">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-154888">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-154888">
                        Arthur Doucette
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-154888">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-154888">
                       <p>
                        What the study showed
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        For pregnant mothers, there was a strong correlation between proximity to agricultural fields where certain pesticides were being sprayed and the likelihood that their children would eventually be diagnosed with autism.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        In total, about one third of the addresses were within 1.5 km (.93 miles) of an agricultural field where one of four different types of pesticideswere sprayed during pregnancy. One class ofpesticides called organophosphates seemed to be especially important: mothers who lived within 1.5 km of fields where they were sprayed had a 54 percent increased chance of having a child diagnosed with autism.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        But the time these pesticides were sprayed during pregnancy seemed to be especially important. If the sprayings occurred during the second trimester of pregnancy, there was an 85 percent increased risk. If it occurred during the third trimester, there was a 107 percent increased risk.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Additionally, there was a link between the total amount of pesticides sprayed and the risk of autism. For every additional 100 pounds of chloropryifos  a type of organophosphate pesticide most often applied to fields of cotton, corn, nuts, and fruit trees  sprayed within a mile of the parents homes during the course of a pregnancy, there was a 14 percent higher chance of having a child diagnosed with autism.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        So heres the GOOD NEWS
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Use of GMOs reduces the use of Organophosphate Insecticides.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-154971">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-154971">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-154971">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-154971">
                          Excuse My Ignorance
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-154971">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-154971">
                         <p>
                          soooo.. instead of blanketing the problems Why dont we just eliminate them permanently and use organic methods of growing so we dont have to deal with these problems?
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-155016">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-155016">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-155016">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-155016">
                          Arthur Doucette
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-155016">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-155016">
                         <p>
                          Well to start with, there is not nearly enough available manure for ~370 million acres of cropland, and the fact is most of the manure that is used in Organic farming comes from non-organic livestock operations and they are largely fed on GMO crops.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Secondly, this is NOT an issue with GMO.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          These crops being sprayed are conventional VEGETABLES not GMO Corn, Soy or Canola.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Third, the yields per acre (and cost per acre) for Organic is such that a total switch (even ignoring the lack of manure problem) would drive up food costs to an unacceptable level.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Scientists from McGill University in Montreal, Canada and the University of Minnesota looked at 66 studies that compared yields of 34 crops grown using organic and conventional methods. They found that crop yields produced using organic methods can be up to 34 percent lower  than those produced using conventional techniques. Organic farming practices appear to be particularly inefficient for grain and vegetable crops. The researchers suggest that lower yields are the result of the types of fertilizers that organic farmers use and how they use them. There is still a big yield difference but the study does suggest organic systems have the potential to produce comparable yields, but only in a very limited number of crops, Sonja Vermeulen, of the Copenhagen-based Consultative Group On International Agricultural Research, told Nature.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Consider today:
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Total Acres Certified Organic:  2011 = 5,383,119
                          <br/>
                          US Total Acres 2011 = 843,866,715
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          So Organic =	0.64%
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          That acreage includes pasture and range land.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          For just cropland
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Certified Organic in 2011 = 3,084,989
                          <br/>
                          US total Acres = 370,653,755
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          So Organic = but 0.83% of our cropland.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-155134">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-155134">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-155134">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-155134">
                          Arthur Doucette
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-155134">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-155134">
                         <p>
                          The vast majority of people cant as they live in Urban areas, Condos, Townhomes or Apartments and dont have access to land. For Suburban dwellers.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          For suburban dwellers, the average lot size is ~1/2 acre, with probably less than half of that available for a garden, or 1/4 acre.  BUT shading from trees effectively makes most suburban yards unfavorable for any but the most modest of gardens.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          So you have to buy land, but farm land is pretty expensive.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Average cost per acre of farmland from USDA  ERS.
                          <br/>
                          Corn Belt		6,980
                          <br/>
                          Northeast		5,280
                          <br/>
                          Lake States		4,660
                          <br/>
                          Pacific		5,820
                          <br/>
                          Appalachian		3,930
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Then farming is a lot of work and it is even harder when you dont have enough to afford the investment in the mechanized tools that larger farms use.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          So heres the conundrum to be able to farm you need to make an adequate living, but thats nearly impossible to do unless your farm is of modest large size.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Indeed, according to USDA data from 2012, intermediate-size farms which gross more than $10,000 but less than $250,000, obtain only 10 percent of their household income from the farm, and 90 percent from an off-farm source. Smaller farms actually lost money farming and earned 109 percent of their household income from off-farm sources.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                          Have you ever read where I suggested people not have a garden?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          No you havent.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          I have a large garden along with a mini-orchard and I have separate beds of berries, asparagus and herbs.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          But that also makes me realistic about how much the typical person can provide for themselves. On a percent basis most wont be able to do that much, and only for about half of the year.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          As to cutting down a lot of pressure on farmers?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Not really.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Consider in the US:
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          US Total Acres 2011 = 843,866,715
                          <br/>
                          That acreage includes ~470 million acres of pasture and range land.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          For just cropland
                          <br/>
                          US total Acres = 370,653,755
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          But Field Crops (field corn, Soy, Wheat, Oats etc), which are not crops that home gardeners can grow was 326,786,000 acres of that crop land.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Fruit trees, Citrus and Tree Nuts accounted for 4 million acres.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          In fact when you take out all the crops that home gardeners are not likely to grow (peanuts, cotton, sugarbeets etc) what is left is ~30 million acres.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Or less than 4% of our crop land.
                         </p>

                          There is approximately 90 millions acres of corn each year.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The average corn yield in 2014 for the US was 165 bpa.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The corn plant needs 1lb of N to produce 1 bushel of corn.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          You would need 14,850,000,000 lbs of N to grow the 2014 corn crop .
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          There is not enough manure in the US to meet that N demand.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Nothing wrong with organics, it just will NOT work on 90 million corn acres and 60 million soybean acres.

                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-155073">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-155073">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-155073">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-155073">
                          Excuse My Ignorance
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-155073">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-155073">

                          when you say N are you speaking of Nitrogen?
                         </p>

                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-155137">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-155137">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-155137">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-155137">
                          Ag Boy
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-155137">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-155137">
                         <p>
                          Yes.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Nitrogen used for corn is usually NH3, Urea, 28/32 % solution, and/or any manure applied.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Grower may use multiply forms of N during the growing season.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          For example in my part of the world a farmer may apply NH3 in the fall with a N stabilizer and use 28/32 solution in the spring when applying their pre-emerge herbicide. It some cases an additional pass with a side dress does happen.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          N applied to each corn crop is based on the corn yield goal, carry over N, weather conditions, N sources available, and economic return.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-153015">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153015">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-153015">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-153015">
                    gamegetter II
                   </span>

                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153015">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153015">
                   <p>
                    Try using facts-not eco-hysteria
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    <a href="http://starvinlarry.com/2015/01/28/database-of-unbiased-publishedpeer-reviewed-gmo-studies/" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://starvinlarry.com/2015/01/28/database-of-unbiased-publishedpeer-reviewed-gmo-studies/', 'http://starvinlarry.com/2015/01/28/database-of-unbiased-publishedpeer-reviewed-gmo-studies/');" rel="nofollow">
                     http://starvinlarry.com/2015/01/28/database-of-unbiased-publishedpeer-reviewed-gmo-studies/
                    </a>
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>

                         </p>
                         <p>
                          This is perfectly supported by the studies I posted and you are making false accusations and strawman arguments as usual.  Ill expose you one last time just to show everyone that you are a complete moron.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          So we are looking for, adverse impact to NTOs at environmentally relevant levels and everyone can see I clearly supported my claim.  Lets look at my response to you :
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Moreover, it was demonstrated that environmentally relevant concentrations of Roundup can pose a health risk for fish populations.
                          <a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20643706" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20643706', 'http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20643706');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20643706
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Fishes were exposed to herbicide at a dose of 4 mgl-1 generally used by farmers to control weedsSevere damage, shrinkage and degeneration of pentagonal cellular contour of stratified epithelial cells (SEC) were observed in gill. Shrinkage of SEC resulting in degeneration of microridges was observed in buccopharynx. Slight necrosed and distorted SEC was observed in oesophagus. Severe mucus secretion was observed in stomach. Erosion on the apical surface of mucosal folds and columnar epithelial cells (CEC) and necrosis of CEC was also noticed in stomach. 
                          <a href="http://www.cabdirect.org/abstracts/20093248244.html;jsessionid=7058798D204C4F4BD05B455F1F4B2FA5" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.cabdirect.org/abstracts/20093248244.html;jsessionid=7058798D204C4F4BD05B455F1F4B2FA5', 'http://www.cabdirect.org/abstracts/20093248244.html;jsessionid=7058798D204C4F4BD05B455F1F4B2FA5');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.cabdirect.org/abstracts/20093248244.html;jsessionid=7058798D204C4F4BD05B455F1F4B2FA5
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          These results indicate that AChE-a neurotoxicity biomarker-in C. decemmaculatus may be affected by exposure to environmentally relevant concentrations of glyphosate.
                          <a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22002176" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22002176', 'http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22002176');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22002176
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The objective of the present study was to evaluate the genotoxic potential of Roundup to blood and liver cells in the Neotropical fish Corydoras paleatus  (Jenyns 1842) following short term exposure (3, 6, and 9 days) to an environmentally realistic concentration of the herbicide (6.67 ug/L Roundup).We conclude that for the low concentration used in this research, the herbicide shows potential genotoxic effects.
                          <a href="http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10661-012-2783-x" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10661-012-2783-x', 'http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10661-012-2783-x');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10661-012-2783-x
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          I can give you a hundred more without really even trying, but that would just be a huge waste of time on an anti-science flatearther.  If you really want more just go to the NTO section here.
                          <a href="http://www.gmofreeusa.org/research/glyphosate/glyphosate-studies/" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.gmofreeusa.org/research/glyphosate/glyphosate-studies/', 'http://www.gmofreeusa.org/research/glyphosate/glyphosate-studies/');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.gmofreeusa.org/research/glyphosate/glyphosate-studies/
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Thanks for the laughs, and good luck with that whole not falling off the Earth thing.  LOL!
                         </p>
                        </div>

                         </p>

                          4 mg/l is 4,000 ug/l. USGS survey data indicates actual glyphosate level in U.S. waterways at less than 10 ug/l.
                         </p>

While in the USA we can debate, argue, talk, present for and against views, in countries like China, India, Pakistan, and many others this is not the case.    Can the USA alone make a difference the chemically altered food chain?

              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-153001">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153001">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-153001">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-153001">
                  TZ
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153001">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153001">
                 <p>
                  There are two main GE crops.One is BT toxin which is an unnatural form of a naturally occurring bacteria which is far more toxic than its natural counterpart, this unnatural bacterium has been genetically engineered into the seed, so this toxin is then expressed in every cell of the plant, so then our corn for example becomes a registered pesticide with the EPAyummy.then there are Roundup Ready crops that have been genetically engineered to withstand heavy doses of Roundup without dying, so mothers get to feed their babies Glyphosate ridden breast milk and the rest of us get to process it though our kidneys and out in our urine..Not to mention the active retro virus called the cauliflower mosaic virus that is used to turn the desired trait on and then the antibiotic marker used to ascertain if the desired trait is being expressed antibiotic resistance anyone? There were never any independent, long-term, minimum of 3 mammalian species, preferably multi-generational studies done to deduce toxicology in human beings concerning the consumption of GMOs. its criminal that they were allowed into our food supply.PERIOD!
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-153016">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153016">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-153016">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-153016">
                    gamegetter II
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153016">

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-154884">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-154884">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-154884">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-154884">
                          Arthur Doucette
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-154884">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-154884">
                         <p>
                          Nope, Ive been over that too many times now.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The study referred to is: U.S. Health in International Perspective: Shorter Lives, Poorer Health by Natl Academy of Sciences
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          They list the REASONS for this and they dont support your argument that Americans arent as healthy, because it is simply looking at why our Life Expectancy isnt as high as other countries.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          And Life Expectancy covers many other issues than health.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Here are the top reasons:
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          1.Adverse birth outcomes: For decades, the United States has experienced
                          <br/>
                          the highest infant mortality rate of high-income countries and also ranks poorly on other birth outcomes, such as low birth weight. ==&gt; Due primarily to very YOUNG MOTHERS
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          2. Injuries and homicides: Deaths from motor vehicle crashes, nontransportation-related injuries, and violence occur at much higher
                          <br/>
                          rates in the United States than in other countries and are a leading
                          <br/>
                          cause of death in children, adolescents, and young adults. Since the
                          <br/>
                          1950s, U.S. adolescents and young adults have died at higher rates
                          <br/>
                          from traffic accidents and homicide than their counterparts in other
                          <br/>
                          countries.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          3. Adolescent pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections: Since
                          <br/>
                          the 1990s, among high-income countries, U.S. adolescents have
                          <br/>
                          had the highest rate of pregnancies and are more likely to acquire
                          <br/>
                          sexually transmitted infections.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          4. HIV and AIDS: The United States has the second highest prevalence
                          <br/>
                          of HIV infection among the 17 peer countries and the highest
                          <br/>
                          incidence of AIDS.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          5. Drug-related mortality: Americans lose more years of life to alcohol
                          <br/>
                          and other drugs than people in peer countries, even when deaths
                          <br/>
                          from drunk driving are excluded.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          6. Obesity and diabetes: For decades, the United States has had the
                          <br/>
                          highest obesity rate among high-income countries. High prevalence
                          <br/>
                          rates for obesity are seen in U.S. children and in every age group
                          <br/>
                          thereafter. From age 20 onward, U.S. adults have among the highest
                          <br/>
                          prevalence rates of diabetes (and high plasma glucose levels)
                          <br/>
                          among peer countries.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          7. Heart disease: The U.S. death rate from ischemic heart disease is
                          <br/>
                          the second highest among the 17 peer countries. Americans reach
                          <br/>
                          age 50 with a less favorable cardiovascular risk profile than their
                          <br/>
                          peers in Europe, and adults over age 50 are more likely to develop
                          <br/>
                          and die from cardiovascular disease than are older adults in other
                          <br/>
                          high-income countries. ==&gt; Primarily from SMOKING and OBESITY
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          8. Chronic lung disease: Lung disease is more prevalent and associated
                          <br/>
                          with higher mortality in the United States than in the United
                          <br/>
                          Kingdom and other European countries. ==&gt; Primarily from SMOKING and SMOG
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The first half of the above list occurs disproportionately among young
                          <br/>
                          Americans. Deaths that occur before age 50 are responsible for about two thirds of the difference in life expectancy between males in the United States
                          <br/>
                          and peer countries, and about one-third of the difference for females.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          In contrast though, the United States has higher survival after age 75 than do
                          <br/>
                          peer countries, and it has higher rates of cancer screening and survival, better
                          <br/>
                          control of blood pressure and cholesterol levels, lower stroke mortality,
                          <br/>
                          lower rates of current smoking, and higher average household income. In
                          <br/>
                          addition, U.S. suicide rates do not exceed the international average
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-155022">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-155022">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-155022">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-155022">
                          Arthur Doucette
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-155022">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-155022">
                         <p>
                          We live longer in comparison to what we were living before.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Thats why you compare same country statistics to see how THAT population is doing relative to what it was.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          US Life Expectancy
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Year Both Male Female Increase
                          <br/>
                          2012  78.8  76.4  81.2
                          <br/>
                          2010  78.7  76.2  81.1  1.2%
                          <br/>
                          2005  77.8  75.2  80.4  1.0%
                          <br/>
                          2000  77.0  74.3  79.7  1.6%
                          <br/>
                          1995  75.8  72.5  78.9  0.5%
                          <br/>
                          1990  75.4  71.8  78.8  0.9%
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Then you can compare our life expectancy to say the UK
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          2012	Both = 80.9, Men =79.0, Women = 82.7
                          <br/>
                          So for US vs UK
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          2012	80.9	vs 78.8	= 2.1 years for Both, = 2.6 years for men,  1.5 years for Women
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          From the report, deaths that occur before age 50 are responsible for about two thirds of the difference in life expectancy between males in the United States and peer countries, and about one-third of the difference for females.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          So the Actual difference in Life Expectancy, after 50 is ~.86 of a year for men and ~.5 a year for women.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Clearly not a huge difference.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          That quote comes from the report your link,  linked to:
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK154469/" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK154469/', 'http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK154469/');" rel="nofollow">

                         <p>
                          John, those numbers are NOT adjusted for population size and age of the population, so are meaningless.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          To start with there are 40 million more of us in 2011 than in 1997, but the oldest are the fastest growing age group thanks to the baby boom years.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          These diseases are of course going to increase in number as the population expands by that amount and also ages.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          A Profile of Older Americans: 2011
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The Older Population
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The older populationpersons 65 years or oldernumbered 40.4 million in 2010 (the most recent year for which data are available). They represented 13.1% of the U.S. population, over one in every eight Americans. The number of older Americans increased by 5.4 million or 15.3% since 2000, compared to an increase of 8.7% for the under-65 population. However, the number of Americans aged 45-64  who will reach 65 over the next two decades  increased by 31% during this period.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.aoa.acl.gov/Aging_Statistics/Profile/2011/3.aspx" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.aoa.acl.gov/Aging_Statistics/Profile/2011/3.aspx', 'http://www.aoa.acl.gov/Aging_Statistics/Profile/2011/3.aspx');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.aoa.acl.gov/Aging_Statistics/Profile/2011/3.aspx
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.census.gov/prod/3/98pubs/p23-194.pdf" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'download', 'http://www.census.gov/prod/3/98pubs/p23-194.pdf');" rel="nofollow">

                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                   </ul>
                   <!-- .children -->
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-155084">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-155084">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-155084">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-155084">
                      TZ
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-155084">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-155084">
                     <p>
                      Nope not BS and it is only common sense that a toxin that is produced at the cellular level cannot be washed off does NOT degrade in sunlight as does the naturally occurring BT toxin.so again toxin laden food producing toxin or doused in it is NOT something I want to eat and should be labeled at the very least.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-155094">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-155094">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-155094">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-155094">
                        Arthur Doucette
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-155094">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-155094">
                       <p>
                        True, it cant be washed off, but Bt bacteria and spores, which contain the Bt cry proteins cant be easily washed off either.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        More to the point, the toxin as you call it, is NOT toxic to humans.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        At all.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        They fed it to mice at the rate of 5,000 mg/kg with NO OBSERVABLE EFFECTS.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        In MON809, cry1A(b) makes up 1.63, 0.55, and 1.23 g/g of leaf, grain, and whole plant tissue, respectively. So what we eat is the grain, which is but 0.55 g/g.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        There are 28 grams in an ounce, so say you eat a pound of corn, thats 448 grams, or 246 g or 0.246 mg per pound of corn.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        Assume you weigh 70 kg and want to keep your ingestion to 1/1000th the level that mice can eat with no ill effects, or just 5 mg/kg (350 mg) then you would have to avoid eating more than 1,400 lbs of corn.
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        So no, it doesnt require a label, in the least.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>

              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-153021">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-153021">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-153021">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-153021">
                  jrcsamad
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-153021">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-153021">
                 <p>
                  Like the cigarette companies, Monsanto continues to defend Roundup  (Glyphosate) as safe to use, but accumulating scientific evidence shows  it could be among the most dangerous products on earth.
                  <br/>
                  The  worlds top selling herbicide is now implicated in a series of epidemics of fatal chronic kidney disease thats affecting poor farming regions  across the world, according to research published in the International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health.
                  <br/>
                  In Sri Lanka, 15% of the population is affected   400,000 patients and  20,000 deaths. Therefore, the president ordered that glyphosate be  banned a couple of weeks ago.
                  <br/>
                  An  investigation carried out by medical specialists and scientists reveals  that kidney disease is mainly caused by Glysophate. President Mahinda  Rajapaksa ordered the immediate removal of Glyphosate from the local  market soon after he heard of the contents of the report, S.M.  Chandrasena, Deputy Minister of Economic Development told reporters. He  said the 25,000 people currently fighting the disease would be assisted  with funds for  medical expenses and clean drinking water.
                  <br/>
                  The paper, Glyphosate, Hard Water and Nephrotoxic Metals: Are They the Culprits Behind the  Epidemic of Chronic Kidney Disease of Unknown Etiology in Sri Lanka?, suggests that a combination of  glyphosate in areas where there are heavy metals in the drinking water can lead to the disease.
                  <br/>
                  Glyphosate acts as a carrier or a vector of these heavy metals to the kidney,  explains Dr. Channa Jayasumana, the studys principal author.
                  <br/>
                  Metals like arsenic and cadmium can be present naturally in the soil or added  by spreading fertilizer. Heavy metals, glyphosate and other herbicides  have been found in urine samples of kidney patients, according to health officials there.
                  <br/>
                  This mysterious form of kidney disease has been  killing tens of thousands of agricultural workers in Central America,  Sri Lanka and India. Although it is completely treatable in wealthier  countries, more people have died from it in El Salvador and Nicaragua  than from diabetes, AIDS and leukemia combined over the last five years, reports Center for Public Integrity.
                  <br/>
                  El Salvador also passed  legislation to ban dozens of agrochemicals including glyphosate last  year, but it has yet to be signed into law.
                  <br/>
                  Watch these 5-minute documentaries, Mystery in the Fields and Cycle of Death for more information on this.
                  <br/>
                  Brazil, Chile Move Against Monsanto
                  <br/>
                  Action against glyphosate is also underway in Brazil, where the  Federal  Public Prosecutor is calling on the Justice Department to ban  it. Other GMO herbicides are also targets: 2,4-D and active ingredients methyl parathion, lactofem, phorate, carbofuran, abamectin, tiram and paraquat, according to GMWatch.
                  <br/>
                  Legal actions have been filed to compel Brazils National Health Surveillance Agency (ANVISA) to reevaluate the toxicity of those active  ingredients. The prosecutor wants the products banned until a final  conclusion is reached.
                  <br/>
                  The previous week, Brazils Federal Appeals Court unanimously ruled to cancel cultivation of Bayers Liberty Link GM Maize.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">

                          Not at all, its been a Win/Win for both Monsanto and Farmers for the last 20 years,
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          <a href="http://www.ers.usda.gov/media/1141089/biotechcrops.png" onclick="__gaTracker('send', 'event', 'outbound-comment', 'http://www.ers.usda.gov/media/1141089/biotechcrops.png', 'http://www.ers.usda.gov/media/1141089/biotechcrops.png');" rel="nofollow">
                           http://www.ers.usda.gov/media/1141089/biotechcrops.png
                          </a>
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The U.S. Department of Agricultures final tally of the 2014 crop year is showing farmers brought in record corn and soybean crops.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The agency says in reports released Monday that farmers harvested a record 14.2 billion bushels of corn. That is 3 percent more than the 2013 crop, which had set the previous record. The average bushel-per-acre yield is 171, significantly better than the 158 bushels per acre in 2013.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The record crop came even though farmers harvested about 5 percent fewer acres than in 2013. Record yields are estimated in 21 states, including Illinois and Nebraska.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Soybean production also is a record at 3.97 billion bushels, up 18 percent from 2013.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          93% of Soybeans are GMO and 90% of Corn is GMO.
                         </p>

                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-154583">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-154583">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-154583">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-154583">
                          Arthur Doucette
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-154583">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-154583">
                         <p>
                          Hardly.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Monsanto organizes its business into dual segments: Seeds and Genomics, and Agricultural Productivity. Today, its seeds and genomics unit (70% of sales) is the companys growth engine. The firms agricultural productivity unit, which serves both farmers and the residential market, makes herbicides under the Roundup, Harness, and other brands for lawn and garden use is but 30% of sales, with a bit over half from sales to farmers.  They ONLY make herbicides, they make no insecticides.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          They are voted the most hated company by people who dont know anything about them.
                          <br/>
                          Farmers though buy their seed year after year after year.
                          <br/>
                          They wouldnt do that if they hated them.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                     </ul>
